title: US economic data drags $A lower
text:
Fri, Jul 3, 2015, 12:20 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 9 hrs 40 mins US economic data drags $A lower AAP – 6 hours ago Print 
The Australian dollar is lower after the release of weak local trade figures and positive US economic data. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday, the currency was trading at 76.34 US cents, down from 77.16 cents on Wednesday. 
During the local session it fell as low as 76.26 US cents, its weakest level since Monday. 
The Australian dollar lost ground after data showed the US manufacturing sector strengthened in June, and 237,000 jobs were added to the US private sector in June. 
RBC senior currency strategist Sue Trinh said the US dollar rose against major currencies, putting downward pressure on the Aussie. 
"Broad based US dollar strength dominated the early Asian session, following through from the north American session," she said. 
The Australian dollar also had a brief dip after the release of local trade data that showed a larger than expected deficit in May, at $2.75 billion. 
"The data continues to highlight the terms of trade and national income challenge," Ms Trinh said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 94.21 Japanese yen, down from Wednesday's close of 94.63 yen, and at 68.94 euro cents, down from 69.36 euro cents. 
Meanwhile, the bond market was weaker as financial markets become a little more optimistic about a bailout for Greece. 
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has vowed to push ahead with a controversial bailout referendum despite pressure from European leaders, and urged creditors to accept a fresh reform offer by Athens. 
Nomura rate strategist Andrew Ticehurst said a better mood has encouraged traders to move out of safe haven assets like bonds. 
"The market has seen stories that the Greek leaders might be prepared to concede more ground in negotiations and the market has taken some comfort from that," he said. 
Mr Ticehurst is unsure whether the situation in Greece will overshadow the Friday release of US non-farm payrolls employment figures, which are usually the most important economic data for global financial markets. 
"If we have no new headlines on Greece then markets will most certainly react to the payrolls data, and conversely if we get significant new headlines from Greece then the market's attention will be somewhat divided again." 
At 1630 AEST on Thursday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 96.845 (implying a yield of 3.155 per cent), down from 96.945 (3.055 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 97.870 (2.130 per cent), down from 97.940 (2.060 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Rio chief shrugs off iron ore pessimism AAP
